Description: Amazon.com, Inc.; Leon Max, Inc.; Macy's, Inc.; and Sears, Roebuck and Co. and its Kmart subsidiaries, Kmart Corporation and Kmart.com, agreed to pay penalties totaling $1.26 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated the Textile Products Identification Act (Textile Act) and the FTC's Textile Rules by labeling and advertising products sold in stores and online as made of bamboo, while they actually were made of rayon.
Info Source: https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2013/01/four-national-retailers-agree-pay-penalties-totaling-126-million

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: Amazon.com Services LLC and Green Messengers Inc.
Description: The Labor Commissioner's Office cited Green Messengers Inc. and Amazon.com Services LLC $6.4 million for wage theft violations affecting 718 workers. The Santa Ana-based contractor delivered packages for Amazon.com Services in Los Angeles, Orange and San Bernardino counties.
Info Source: https://www.dir.ca.gov/DIRNews/2021/2021-27.html

Description: The EPA announced the settlement of allegations that Amazon committed nearly four thousand violations of the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) dating back to 2013 for selling and distributing imported pesticide products that were not licensed for sale in the United States.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.epa.gov/enforcement/amazon-services-llc-fifra-settlement
Notes: Note: This penalty is a duplicate of an amount shown in another record (either because it applies to a multi-location settlement or because Violation Tracker contains an agency record and a settlement announcement for the same case).

Private Litigation Case Title: Speer v. Whole Foods Market Group, Inc.
Info Source: https://topclassactions.com/lawsuit-settlements/lawsuit-news/161350-whole-foods-settles-background-check-class-action-lawsuit-for-803k/
https://www.law360.com/articles/1063919/amazon-seeks-to-end-fcra-suits-with-5m-in-gift-cards

Description: Amazon agreed to pay the penalties of VHU Express, Inc., which was fined for failing to pay employees in a timely manner, in violation of Massachusetts wage and hour laws.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20160402102626/http://www.mass.gov/ago/news-and-updates/press-releases/2016/2016-03-29-amazon-contractor.html

Description: Amazon.com Inc. and Amazon Services LLC agreed to pay $122,000 in refunds and credit in settlement of allegations it violated Iowa's Buying Club Membership law, which requires certain notices and disclosures designed to make the enrollment process clear to consumers.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20170323192132/https://www.iowaattorneygeneral.gov/newsroom/amazon-agrees-to-refund-1-100-iowa-amazon-prime-customers/

Description: Settlement of allegations relating to the sale of toy guns that look like real guns.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20161008122521/http://www.ag.ny.gov/press-release/ag-schneiderman-cracks-down-illegal-toy-guns-sales-announces-settlements-amazon

Description: Amazon agreed to pay $700,000 as part of a settlement in which it committed to a nationwide effort to get chromium and lead removed from children's school supplies.
Info Source: https://www.atg.wa.gov/news/news-releases/ag-ferguson-amazon-must-remove-toxic-school-supplies-kid-s-jewelry-marketplace

Description: Zappos.com entered into a $106,000 settlement with nine states to resolve issues relating to a 2012 data breach that exposed the personal information of the website's consumers. The settlement required Zappos to undertake additional security measures to help prevent future data breaches.
Info Source: http://www.marylandattorneygeneral.gov/press/2015/010715.pdf

Description: Amazon.com agreed to pay $100,000 in settlement of allegations it unlawfully sold force-fed foie gras in California. The agreement was reached with the Los Angeles, Monterey, and Santa Clara County district attorneys.
Info Source: http://da.lacounty.gov/media/news/district-attorneys-reach-settlement-amazon-prohibit-force-fed-foie-gras-sales-california

Company: Whole Foods Market California Inc., Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Markets Inc., and WFM-WO Inc.
Description: Whole Foods and two related entities agreed to pay $1,643,500 in settlement of allegations by 22 California District and City Attorneys that they violated California laws for storage, handling and disposal of hazardous waste from products used or sold at their stores.
Info Source: https://www.alcoda.org/newsroom/2018/sep/whole_foods_settlement#more

Description: Amazon.com agreed to pay $1,512,400 in settlement of allegations by 23 California District Attorneys that it misleadingly labeled plastic products as biodegradable or compostable. Amazon also agreed to make an additional payment of $50,000 to CalRecycle to fund testing of plastic products marketed to consumers as compostable or degradable.
Info Source: https://www.sacda.org/media/news-archives-2/2018-press-release-archives/8118-da-anne-marie-schubert-announces-consumer-protection-settlement-amazon/

Company: Whole Foods Market California, Inc., and Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Markets, Inc.
Description: Whole Foods Market California, Inc., and Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Markets, Inc. agreed to pay nearly $800,000 in settlement of allegations by the City Attorneys of Santa Monica, Los Angeles and San Diego that they overcharged customers at checkouts, failed to deduct the weight of containers in self-serve areas, and sold food items charged by the piece instead of by the pound.
Info Source: https://www.sandiego.gov/sites/default/files/nr140624.pdf

Description: Whole Foods agreed to pay $500,000 in settlement of allegations it labeled pre-packaged products with inaccurate prices.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/dca/media/pr122815.page
https://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=20536

https://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=15754
https://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=20474

Agency: California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation
Info Source: https://dbo.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/296/2020/02/Consent-Order-Amazon-Capital-Services-Inc.pdf
https://real.flofr.com/datamart/searchFinalOrderFLOFR.do

Description: Amazon.com agreed to pay $134,523 to settle its potential civil liability for apparent violations of multiple OFAC sanctions programs. As a result of deficiencies related to Amazon's sanctions screening processes, it provided goods and services to persons sanctioned by OFAC; to persons located in the sanctioned region or countries of Crimea, Iran, and Syria; and to individuals located in or employed by the foreign missions of countries sanctioned by OFAC. Amazon also failed to timely report several hundred transactions conducted pursuant to a general license issued by OFAC that included a mandatory reporting requirement, thereby nullifying that authorization with respect to those transactions.
Info Source: https://home.treasury.gov/system/files/126/20200708_amazon.pdf
https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/whole-foods-market-california-incorporated-case-settlement

Company: Whole Foods Market California, Inc., and Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Markets, Inc.
Info Source: https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/whole-foods-market-california-inc-mrs-goochs-natural-food-markets-inc-settlement
https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/amazoncom-llc-settlement-2015
https://ww2.arb.ca.gov/amazoncom-inc-settlement
Contained in data obtained from the agency on October 6, 2020 in response to an open records request.

Description: VADATA agreed to pay $261,638 in settlement of allegations its data centers had installed and/or operated diesel electrical generator sets without air emission permits or outside of permit requirements.
Info Source: https://www.deq.virginia.gov/permits-regulations/enforcement/final-orders

Description: The District Attorneys of California's Alameda, San Diego, Santa Cruz, Santa Clara, Yolo and Riverside Counties obtained a $2 million dollar civil judgment in a consumer protection lawsuit against e-commerce giant Amazon.com in a case alleging that the company's reference price advertisements were either misleading, or potentially misleading, to consumers making purchasing decisions.
Info Source: https://www.alcoda.org/newsroom/2021/mar/amazon_settlement

Description: Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission has approved a final administrative consent order against Amazon, which has agreed to pay more than $61.7 million to settle charges that it failed to pay Amazon Flex drivers the full amount of tips they received from Amazon customers over a two and a half year period.
Info Source: https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2021/06/ftc-approves-final-administrative-consent-order-against-amazon
https://www.in.gov/idem/oe/cause/AO/26833-H.htm

Agency: New York City Commission on Human Rights
Info Source: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/cchr/enforcement/2018-settlements.page

Description: Amazon agreed to pay $13.5 million to resolve multidistrict claims brought by thousands of distribution center workes not compensated for time spent in mandatory security checks. The settlement ended an 11-year-old legal battle.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Amazon.com, Inc., Fulfillment Center Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1405839/-13-5m-deal-ends-amazon-wage-mdl-that-went-to-high-court

Description: Amazon agreed to pay $2.5 million in settlement of allegations it sold regulated agricultural and industrial-use pesticides in the state without a license and without collecting required use information.
Info Source: https://www.atg.wa.gov/news/news-releases/ag-ferguson-amazon-will-pay-25-million-over-illegal-sales-regulated-pesticides

Description: Amazon agreed to pay $2.25 million in settlement of allegations its Sold by Amazon program was unlawful price-fixing, making agreements with third-party sellers guaranteeing certain levels of payment for sales in exchange for their agreement to stop competing with Amazon in the pricing of their products.
Info Source: https://www.atg.wa.gov/news/news-releases/ag-ferguson-investigation-shuts-down-amazon-price-fixing-program-nationwide

Agency: South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District
Info Source: http://www.aqmd.gov/docs/default-source/Agendas/Governing-Board/2014/2014-oct3-017.pdf?sfvrsn=2

Description: Amazon agreed to pay $500,000 as part of a settlement of allegations the company had harmful labor practices that concealed Covid case numbers from workers and to provide key information on workplace protections in line with California's right-to-know law.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/nationwide-first-attorney-general-bonta-secures-judgment-requiring-amazon-comply
